title: 112_s1581
content: The Act is titled the "FAIR Enforcement Against Duty Evasion Act of 2011" and it terminates the availability of bonds for new shippers under the Tariff Act of 1930. It also addresses the collection of identification relating to importers. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include regulations for customs brokers and their customers to identify the customer importing merchandise into the United States. This includes implementing procedures to collect the identity of importers. Customs brokers must collect information on non-United States persons importing merchandise into the United States, including name, address, and other identifying details. Failure to comply may result in penalties up to $10,000 per violation and potential license suspension or revocation. The Secretary will establish safe harbors for specified practices to avoid penalties under subsection (d) within 60 days of enactment. Proposals will be solicited and accepted for a 60-day period, followed by a notice in the Federal Register for comment. Final regulations on specified practices exempt from penalties will be issued before the end of 1 year. The subsection will take effect within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 180 days with recommendations on requiring foreign nationals to provide customs brokers with necessary information. Establishing a system for customs brokers and agencies to verify the identities of foreign and US nationals importing merchandise into the US under 641(i) of the Tariff Act of 1930. The establishment of an importer of record database is mandated under section 4, to verify the identities of individuals importing goods into the US. Improvements to the importer of record database include adding a history of importer of record numbers, evaluating database accuracy, preventing duplicate numbers, updating the database annually, and enabling customs brokers to verify required information. The Tariff Act of 1930 requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to report to the Senate and House committees on the improvements made to the importer of record program within one year of the Act's enactment.
